label: None

Document: side language subtraction inverse side tile side
Name: -1_school_year_time_people
Top_n_words: school - year - time - people - child - teacher - thing - today - week - book
original_text: 4/n balancing both sides and the language you use is key. It is more useful to talk about subtraction as the additive inverse than "taking from both sides." While it feels ok to just remove positive tiles from both sides...
label: None

Document: idea pair term removal side point something
Name: -1_school_year_time_people
Top_n_words: school - year - time - people - child - teacher - thing - today - week - book
original_text: 5/n this idea breaks down when you are trying to form a zero pair with a negative term. "Removal" from both sides doesn't work so what is the point in teaching something that is not easily generalised?
label: None

Document: question time equation student structure equation
Name: -1_school_year_time_people
Top_n_words: school - year - time - people - child - teacher - thing - today - week - book
original_text: 6/n Ask what it questions at all times... y + 2 = 11 What if I changed this to 2 + y = 11 or 11 = y + 2. By showing the different ways an equation can be written, allows students to better understand the underlying structure of the equation when it is written differently
label: None

Document: teacher example equation form practice idea practice memory idea time variation
Name: -1_school_year_time_people
Top_n_words: school - year - time - people - child - teacher - thing - today - week - book
original_text: 7/n I see teachers showing 3y+4=16 as an example and then give LOTS of these equations in this form as practice with the idea that "massed practice" helps muscle memory. I feel this idea is flawed and would rather spend more time in the I do, we do phase to show this variation
label: None
